_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: Changed settings on ammonia sensors for different process areas; Installed manual shut-off switch

_prev_prog_3.CT_OtherType: Certified approval from training coordinator and/or other authorized person

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.0  EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Pursuant to the requirements of Title 40 Code of Federal Regulations Part 68.1 through 68.220 and Chapter 6.95, Article 2 of the California Health & Safety Code §25531 through §25543.3, this federal Risk Management Plan (RMP) is implemented as the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program.

The scope of this RMP is based on the guidance of the Certified Unified Program Agency (CUPA), the city of Oxnard Fire Department, to ensure that all contemporary issues are resolved and to incorporate state requirements.  With input from the CUPA, the use of anhydrous ammonia (CAS 7664-41-7) in a closed-loop refrigeration process and under a separate process, anhydrous ammonia will be used in a Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) system to control nitrogen oxides (NOX) emissions from a one Mega Watt natural gas fired turbine.  These processes at the facility trigger the CalARP/RMP requirements.  These processes were determined to be covered by Prevention Program 3 requirements.

On March 31, 2004, the amendment to the Chemical Accident Prevention Rule (Risk Management Program) under the Clean Air Act Section 112 (r) (7) was signed. The amendment:

¿	Requires a correction to reportable information on chemical accidents be added to the RMP within six (6) months of the date of the accident;
¿	Requires that changes to emergency contact information be corrected within one (1) month;
¿	Removes the requirement to include a brief description of the off-site consequence analysis (OCA) in the RMP executive summary; and
¿	Adds three (3) RMP data elements.

EPA also amended the RMP*Submit format to expand the list of possible accident causes to include uncontrolled chemical reactions.  As part of this rulemaking, EPA also clarified that the five (5) year deadline for updating RMPs that were originally filed early (i.e., submitted before June 21, 1999), is June 21, 2004.  This amendment became effective on April 9, 2004 when it was published in the Fed

eral Register.

1.1  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Gills Onions has a policy to protect its employees, environment, property, and the general public from any harm that may occur as a result of its operations.  To achieve this end, Gills Onions strives to operate its facilities in compliance with applicable federal, state, and local safety, health, and environmental regulations.  

Gills Onions emergency response policies are implemented to comply with the overall company policy of providing its workers with a safe workplace and minimizing risk to the public.  The safety of emergency and non-affected personnel must have priority; therefore, all procedures must be carried out in the appropriate manner.  Only then can safely executed rescue and medical activities be considered.  Another priority is protection of the environment.  Only after life, safety, and environmental concerns are addressed will the focus shift to the secondary issues of property conservation and business recovery.

1.2  Facility Description

Oxnard is located on the southern margin of the Oxnard Plain, approximately 5 miles inland from the Pacific Ocean and approximately 50 miles west of Los Angeles, California.  The elevation of the facility is approximately 35 feet above sea level.  The nearest earthquake faults are the Pitas Point-Ventura Fault, approximately 8 miles to the northwest and the Anacapa (Dume) Fault, approximately 16 miles to the southwest located in the Pacific Ocean.  The Anacapa (Dume) Fault produced a 5.9 magnitude earthquake in 1973. 

The facility is located in a limited industrial (M-2) zone at 1051 South Pacific Avenue.  The facility covers approximately 14 acres and is bounded on the north by Mountain View Avenue, on the east by Pacific Avenue and on the south by Wooley Road.  The Ventura County Railway Spur runs along the western property line which is shared with other light industrial facilities to the west. The nearest major highway is

State Route 1, the Pacific Coast Highway, approximately 0.5-miles to the west.  A map of the area is shown in Figure 1-1.

The nearest residential area, East Ash Street, is approximately 0.5-miles to the southwest.  The next nearest residential area, La Puerta Street in La Colonia neighborhood, is approximately 0.65 miles to the northeast.  The Oxnard Community Center Complex is approximately 1.25-miles to the west and the Center Point Mall is approximately 1.1 miles to the southwest.  These are considered public receptors under the RMP regulation. The nearest environmental receptor is a Natural Preserve approximately 6 miles northwest of the facility.  The Natural Preserve is located just north of McGrath State Beach on the Santa Clara River outlet to the Pacific Ocean.

The facility is designed to process and store onions.  Processing includes washing, peeling, dicing, and packaging onions.  The cold storage room, shipping dock, and receiving vestibule are designed to store onions at 34°F by means of the ammonia refrigeration system.  A block flow diagram of the refrigeration system is contained in Appendix A along with applicable piping and instrument diagrams (P&IDs).  The refrigeration system is designed to cool indoor air in processing rooms to approximately 40-50°F, to 34°F in cold storage, and to chill process water to below 40°F.

Major process steps include the following:

a)	compression;
b)	condensers;
c)	high pressure receiver;
d)	pumping units;
e)	evaporators, air handling units, and water chillers
f)	diffuser (emergency only). 

The entire system has the capacity to hold 20,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia in a closed loop system.  
1.3  Regulated Substances

Anhydrous ammonia (CAS 7664-41-7) under pressure: 20,000 pounds in a closed-loop refrigeration process at pressure and temperature ranges of 38 to 154 psig and +24 to 160°F in both vapor and liquid states (depending on process step).  

Under a separate process, anhydrous ammonia (CAS 7664-41-7) un

der pressure: 1,200 pounds will be used in a Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) system to control nitrogen oxides (NOX) emissions from a one Mega Watt natural gas fired turbine.  This process utilizes anhydrous ammonia in the capacity of a SCR for the Best Available Control Technology (BACT).  The SCR system reduces NOX  emissions by injecting ammonia into the exhaust gas stream upstream of a catalyst matrix.  Nitrogen oxides, ammonia, and oxygen react on the surface of the catalyst to form nitrogen and water.  The catalyst is comprised of a noble metal and works within a high temperature range for proper operations (800° F to 1100°F).  As such, the control efficiency of the SCR system is reducing NOX emissions to about 90 percent.

1.4  Five-Year Accident History

Since the facility¿s construction in 1999, there have been no recorded incidents.

1.5	Prevention Program

In addition to implementation of the RMP Prevention Program 3 elements, Gills Onions has implemented specific safety features for the prevention, detection and control of releases of regulated (and other) substances at the facility.  The following are some of the control and detection equipment located in and around the facility to minimize the risk of an accident involving hazardous materials at the Gills Onions Facility:

¿	Relief and/or safety valves
¿	Emergency Control Stations
¿	Fire Protection System
¿	Emergency Shutdown Systems (ESD)
¿	Leak Alarms
 
Compliance with RMP and CalARPs comprehensive program ensures the integrity of the processes which handle flammable or toxic materials.  The objective of the regulation is to prevent unwanted releases of hazardous chemicals.   To control these types of hazards, Gills Onions has developed the necessary expertise, experiences, judgement and proactive initiative within their workforce to properly implement and maintain an effective prevention program. Through compliance with the regulations and standards and with the guidance of the Certified Unified

Program Agency, CUPA, Gills Onions has implemented the requirements of the Prevention Program 3.  

An effective program requires a systematic approach to evaluating the whole chemical process. Using this approach the following components were considered in the evaluation in accordance with Title 19 CCR 68 Section 2745.6 and 40 CFR part 68.  

The twelve elements that make up the Prevention Program 3 are:

1.	Process Safety Information;
2.	Process Hazard Analysis [PHA].;
3.	Operating Procedures;
4.	Training;
5.	Mechanical Integrity;
6.	Management of Change
7.	Pre-Startup Review
8.	Compliance Audits;
9.	Incident Investigation;
10.	Employee Participation
11.	Hot Work Permit
12.	Contractors

1.6	Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Gills Onions has developed a Process Safety Management (PSM) Program pursuant to Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) guidelines (i.e., 8 CCR §5189) for the refrigeration process handling ammonia.  The PSM program is designed to ensure safety for employees and minimize the risk of accidental releases and injuries.  Gills Onions implemented the PSM program on June 18, 1999.  The PSM document was revised and updated in October 2002 as a result of a CalOSHA inspection. 

The PSM program¿s process safety information includes detailed description of ammonia hazards, process hazards, and prevention steps.  Chemical-specific prevention steps include:

¿	Nine (9) ammonia detectors
¿	Alarms: horns and beacon lights
¿	Emergency control panel linked to independent alarm systems controller to notify local emergency crews (i.e., fire department, police, etc.)
¿	Emergency shut-down switches
¿	Relief valves to header leading to ammonia diffuser tank 
¿	pH monitors 


The PSM Program will apply to storage and handling of ammonia for the refrigeration and natural gas-fired turbine¿s SCR system.


1.7  Emergency Response Program Summary

Gills Onions has developed written emergency response procedures to address all elements that may be encoun

rgency shut-off switch, different ammonia detection settings, a battery backup system for emergency fan in engine room, and a battery backup system for emergency light, security fences (8 ft X 20 ft block walls), and increased lighting.  An Emergency Control Panel has been installed for the ammonia refrigeration system.  This system is linked to independent alarm system controller to notify emergency personnel.  A control panel of the same configuration will be installed for the SCR system.  A wind sock will be erected in the middle of the east wall of the ammonia storage tank.  It will be about twelve to fourteen inches and stand about sixteen feet high.  This wind sock will be used to indicate hazardous materials on site.
